708670f.text:
Fifth Avenue north from 4lst Street, showing pupils of the Spence School for Girls out for their daily walk.
At the extreme left is the reservoir which for many years covered the site now occupied by the New York Public Library. In the left background is the Bristol office building, formerly the Hotel Bristol.
This was demolished in 1929 to make way for the Salmon Tower. The spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral may be dimly seen in the right background.
Temple Emanu-El, demolished in 1927 is the spired building in the centre.
1900.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

708692f-a.text:

Building, at the N.W. corner of West 42nd Street.
March 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

708789f-b.text:
(1)
Fifth Avenue, east side, from 41st to 42nd Streets, from steps of the New York Public Library. In the foreground may be seen part of a picket line which was conducted for some weeks against the Fifth Avenue Omnibus Company in connection with the discharge of twentyseven employees. The outcome of the dispute is unknown.
July 6, 1935.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
A view at 42nd Street.
July 2, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

708716f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., west side, north from 41st to 42nd (right) Streets, showing the north wing of the Central Building of the New York Public Library as photographed at dusk (6:30 P.M.). Skyscrapers on the north side of West 42nd Street are in their order, the No. 500 Fifth Ave.
Building; the Salmon Towers and the Aeolian Building.
March 17, 1938.
Mr. Nathan Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

708708f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., west side, at 41st Street (main entrance to the
N. Y. P. L).
A photo showing "Beauty' seated on "Pegasus" and mounted in the south niche. This is by Frederick Macmonnies. For further data, see The History of the New York Public Library by H.M. Lydenberg (page
509).
July 14, 1936.
ift of G.D. Chinn.

708729f-a.text:
Street Scenes: Political harangue on the New York Public Library steps in the Roosevelt-Wilkie presidential contest. This speaker is pro-Roosevelt; the Wilkie orator is to the left and not shown. In the right background is the base of the office structure, No.
500 Fifth Avenue.
Fall 1940
Nathan Schwartz, phoko
N.Y.P.L. Photostat div.

708730f.text:
Street Scenes: Political harangue on the New York Public Library Steps in the Roosevelt-Wilkie presidential contest. This speaker is pro-Roosevelt; the Wilkie orator is to the left and not shown. Incidentally, the latter meking use of a mlcraphone drew larger crowds. Credit for the adaptioniof this technic should be given to the U. S. Senatorial candidate, Bruce Barton, an advertising
erecutive.
Fall 1940
Nathan Schwartz, photo
N.Y.P.L. Photostat div.

708746f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., east side, south from East 42nd to 4lst Streets. Building shown, is Rutgers Female College (founded 1838 by Chancellor Ferris). This photograph was presented to the graduating olass of 1875. This institution lost this property, at a later date, and moved to 56 West 55th
Street.
1875.
Gift of Mrs. C.M. Benson.

731212f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - U. S. Grant's Funeral.
731212f-a.text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The General U. S. Grant funeral procession moving northward on Fifth Avenue as photographed from 41st Street atop the old reservoir. The dominant structure with flag atop is the Union League Club at the N. E. corner of 39th Street.
August 8, 1885
H. N. Tiemann, Photo
00ift of Urbrock Collection
